text: Absolutely. Thank you, Mr. Alcaro. Good morning, board members. My name is Pat McLaughlin. I'm chief of strategic planning for the school division. And in recent weeks, we've shared with you some updated version of our school calendars. And today, we'd like you to take action by selecting a start date for the 2020-2021 school year.  I'll begin with a quick reminder of our timeline. On June 18, we shared with you the results of our calendar survey, and also shared with you our return to school planning guide, which you spent some time unpacking on the 19th. This week and next, we've been meeting with principals and department leaders about possible scheduling scenarios for next year, and today we'll launch a survey for our families to provide feedback about their plans for next year.  Today, we'd like the board to vote in a start date for the 2020-2021 school year, and at our meeting on July 9th, staff will present an attendance schedule for the year. Based on a number of factors, including teachers' desire for additional preparation time, the results of our calendar survey, and the planning of our school schedules, which are beginning to come into greater focus, staff is recommending that we start school on Tuesday, September 8th.  It's important to note that this year's calendar will need to be somewhat fluid and will likely undergo additional modifications once a return to school scheduling plan has been adopted. For example- Did you stop your presentation?
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: I did, yep. I just had that one slide up there.
speaker: christinethompso

text: Yep. Sorry. That's okay. For example, if students are not in school every day and we have a built-in planning and development days for teachers each week, we would not need to delineate these days as non-student days in the calendar like we have in the past.  Students would be accessing school on these days, and we would plan to count them as part of the 180 days of the school year. This would allow us to shift the final day of the school year to an earlier date. Should we enter a phase of recovery during the school year that allows all students to return to school in person, that could also have an impact on the calendar. However, our traditional school breaks, including Thanksgiving, winter, and spring break, would not be changed so that families can make plans for these holidays.  We also realized that each of the September date calendar, September start date calendars that we've shared with the board had the final school day where the Juneteenth holiday would be observed next year. We will not have school on this day for students or staff next year and believe our final day of school would likely be earlier that week with the modifications that we may make to the calendar.  Finally, I wanna let the board know that this week we met with the executive leadership team of the Charlottesville City Schools to share our thinking behind our return to school plan and our updated calendar drafts. We'll meet with them again in coming weeks to discuss the board's decision today as they plan for next year. So if there are any questions prior to taking action, I'll be happy to address them now.
